p.s: William Shakespeare? How Germans adore Shakespeare
We all know William Shakespeare as a crosscultural literary figure famous for tragedies like Romeo and Julia or Macbeth.
But how does the English writer and poet got his universal appeal?
How does Shakespeare become the most frequently performed playwright in the whole world?
Today, we will be discussing how his work become famous in central Europe, particularly in Germany.
I found an informative article dealing how Shakespeare carved his way into German literature.
Firstly, the most important contibutionscontributions for the Shakespearean rise in German speaking countries made Christoph Martin Wieland.
Klaus Manger, professor from Jena for Germanistikstates that Wieland was the first ever German to translate various Shakespearean dramas.

Even though there already awere hints of other famous German writers like Goethe or Herder of reading the work of the English writer, Wieland was primarily the one who contributed to ShakespearShakespeare being well-known.
Between 1762 and 1766 22 of his translationtranslations were published in Zurich, marking the beginning of the rise.
The translation was slightly different from the original, Wieland left some unpropriate parts out, in order to protect the high society.
However, it only brought more attention to the unique work of Shakespeare.
Some years later, particularly, on the 8 April 1864 the Shakespearean Society was born.
In higher ranked society people like to read the Shakespearean comedies, tragedies, sonnets or narrative poem.
Together they created the union of Shakespeare friends and on his birthday they gatehred together to celebrate his exellenceexcellence.
As some histories were presented by actors it inspired the people to found an officalofficial union, the Shakespeare society which now is the oldest literary club in Germany.
All this happened in the cultural city Weimar.
Weimar is now seen as the birth place of Shakespearean work spreading in Germany.
340 years later a statue of the famous writer was placed in the Weimarer parcpark.
We can see how the author oveseas influenced the city, even though he was already dead.
Today this club of classical literature is a part of Unesco inheritance.
